Eliza, thou boast of the plain,</br>Thou pride of my pastoral muse,</br>O!  listen, my fair, to the strain,</br>Which Isis in vain can refuse.
All nature deplores the late year,</br>And echo's its joys are away;</br>In vain shall its pastimes appear,</br>And bid us be careless and gay.
Yet Aries revives us agin,</br>And asks the fond incense and pray'r;</br>"Be candid, and banish her pain,</br>Be fairest Eliza thy care."
O!  let her around the long year,</br>In pleasure and innocence rove;</br>Oh!  bid her be blest as she's fair;</br>Oh!  bid her be true as her love.
And when you return to my fair,</br>Oh!  let her in silence reply,</br>"In peace I have trac'd the gay year,</br>In peace I contented can die."
Remote, in the cloistered vale,</br>Where science reclines on her bays,</br>Thy swain (may his wishes prevail!)</br>Thy swain with sincerity prays.
Then fairest Eliza adieu!</br>And while by the side of the grove</br>You muse, and our pleasure review,</br>Where oft I have whisper'd my love.
Remember thy languishing swain,</br>Nor list to thy suitors around;</br>Oh!  fly from the artful and vain,</br>For all my fond heart is thy own.</br>
